snippet: The justices will reckon with Congress’s power to address persistent discrimination.
abstract: Editorial urges Supreme Court to uphold validity of Section 5 of 1965 Voting Rights Act, which requires states with histories of racial discrimination to get permission from federal government before making changes to voting rules; argues Shelby County v Holder, case before court in which Alabama county questions constitutionality of section, does not take into account that 40 years is not enough time to eliminate persistent voter discrimination.
lead_paragraph: The justices will reckon with Congress’s power to address persistent discrimination.

headline.seo: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Right-to-Vote Case
headline.main: A Supreme Test on the Right to Vote
headline.print_headline: A Supreme Test on the Right to Vote
